8fBlRGfD0FfEEoIz8IcQTQ.text: Overpriced, over-hyped place trying to be an American eatery.Tiny portions, cold expresso..I wanted to like this place because the decor is reminiscent of a NY west village joint, unfortunately the food looks and tastes all too much like some crappy English seaside town cafe.

awDCNVm-gSu1JZU0dn6VyA.text: ...average.  Really liked the steak, and the server was excellent. (tho young)the bar certainly offers a nice selection of cocktails; however a bit light on the booz for our group.recommend this spot for a try.  but certainly, we preferred the old Union Jacks.

YiotBojAc5B3ATBdz0SKVg.text: I'll be honest and admit that I had very low expectations for Jackson + Rye (yet another American-style eatery) when I went there last Saturday. I needed a place to eat a big meal in the middle of the afternoon to satiate me before seeing a five hour screening + Q&A of Nymphomaniac, and J+R's all-day brunch menu fit the bill. We ordered the fried calamari starter, the roast chicken, the fried chicken, a side of the tomato-basil salad, and a (very reasonably priced) glass of prosecco. The calamari was fair - nothing memorable. The roast chicken was surprisingly juicy and flavorful, and was the clear highlight of the meal. (Though the creamy dipping sauce that came on the side was coagulated and inedible.) The fried chicken was also well-executed. The tomato salad was a joke, unfortunately. It looked like they took a carton of Tesco cherry tomatoes, sliced them in half, and threw some old chopped basil on top. Shame on me for ordering a tomato salad in February, but shame on them for serving this dish.It is clear that two people can have markedly different experiences here, depending on what they order. Based on the dishes served to other tables, the fried chicken sandwich seems to be a popular option, as are the (poor-looking) American pancakes. If I went back I would probably stick with the roast chicken or potentially try an egg dish. I am giving this place three stars for the chicken dishes, which were enjoyable and reasonably priced.

spsD75u4X-CvKyTgPF_SVg.text: Dark moody lighting and 60s motown - I loved the ambience of Jackson & Rye. The widely regarded buttermilk fried chicken didn't disappoint and went well with the side of American mac & cheese. In fact, I could've done with MORE mac & cheese - maybe I'll try the starter next time rather than the side. The meatballs were an underrated dish; I always think it's hard to make meatballs exciting, but they did very well with their seasoning.The only boo-boo was the peanut cookies at the end were a bit hard like shortbread when they would've been a lot better chewy - it would've made a wonderful gooey mess with the milk ice cream.

eel5gb_8Zd5aq0Djh4qfhg.text: Loved the food and the decor. The service wasn't so great because there seemed to be a bit of miscommunication going on between the staff. Although we were being served by three different servers we had to remind them a couple times that something from our order was missing.

photos.caption: Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom. Pancakes with oranges and chocolate sauce
Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom. Farmer's breakfast

w_u7AMVA2OtC1A9YL_BizA.text: Walked in here at 6:30 table and got seated quickly without reservation (muy bueno).Service was a bit haphazard (no bueno).Fried chicken was pretty good. I'm kind of a KFC aficionado (US style man. Don't give me this UK KFC stuff) and I was pleased it was decent. Also ordered the steak, which was fine as steak goes.What I loved the most was the selection of whiskey and cocktails here. They have a solid repertoire of alch, my alcoholic friends.

cI5Tr8t79i3Lb5lL8XjNYw.text: I've been here a couple of times for brunch.The first time, I ordered the buttermilk pancakes - 3 pancakes served with ricotta and maple syrup. I ordered a portion of slab bacon on the side, which I found went well with the pancakes. The avocado Benedict was also a nice alternative for those who love avocado - this came filled with bacon bits as well.On my second visit me and my friend ordered a few to share. I liked the crab cakes which came with a side of slaw. A bit mixed about the prawn and grits, not quite sure I liked the grits that much, although the prawns were quite fresh and juicy.I have a sweet tooth and liked the blueberry cobbler, it's quite a big portion and I'd recommend it to share between 2.Food on the whole wasn't too bad, although I can't say the same about service. The waitresses weren't that attentive, and some didn't look very friendly. It took quite long for someone to come take our orders. And also a long time for our bill to arrive after we had requested it. Overall, a bit hit and miss...For a full post with photos, click here: dancing-in-high-heels.bl…

photos.caption: Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom. Slab bacon
Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom. Prawns and grits

-Dgg6y-cnlGb2FbwsEByjA.text: I had Farmers plate and it was just great. Great service, great brunch and wonderful place.

DK3XmVsjoAcSXEwsCKxJvQ.text: My rib eye steak, was served medium instead of medium rare as I requested, it lacked seasoning and the quality of the meat was very questionable. It was hardly tender at all and the meaty flavour you would expect from an aged cut of meat was missing, at £18.95, I was really hoping for something a lot better considering you can get quality steak elsewhere such as Flat Iron which is just down the road. The baked mac and cheese was also far from ideal, the cheese was only piled on the top and was completely separate from the macaroni, it seems like a lack of attention to detail from the kitchen.

kDehslB9oSMBEVdc-s5BeQ.text: Amazing atmosphere! Their menu is lovely and diverse. The buttermilk fried chicken with sweet potato fries is divine, however it is a little heavy! The cocktail menu is quite impressive for a restaurant and very fairly priced. Definitely a go to place with smaller parties of 3-4...  The staff is very friendly and professional! I will definitely return!

XOdqFNzwFH8xNkXfQQEDRQ.text: Great brunch - we booked at 10am on a Sunday and by 11am there were massive queues out of the door. Appreciate that they were busy but the second we put our forks down the waiter was hovering and clearly very keen for us to go - something to be aware of if you're hoping for a long catch up!

iTb5KX20oHM09QPn4PzYkw.text: I love this place, the atmosphere, the food, and even the price is all just fantastic. In the center of bustling soho, this old school new york style restaurant/bar has a great menu for drinks and food. Would definitely recommend!

g9tx2jLn7THs74rvRUYGyg.text: The vibe is good but everything else was just average. Maybe because the dishes sound so appealing but the reality is a bit different. PB cookies for example should be gooey and yummy and not flat and white and bland........The service was also just average. Too many places in London to try so unlikely to go back for a second chance. Read full review on my blog.

k2ui1yupPCqRv0QWlXxAuw.text: Found this gem while wondering through soho in desperate search of brunch (a more difficult task than one would think ) arrived to extremely friendly staff who welcomed us in and got us table straight away. I opted for the buttermilk pancakes with banana cream and the slab bacon (the slab bacon is particularly worth mentioning , sinfully good)  it was absolutely delicious , not a dish for one on a diet but if indulging I recommend. My dining partner had a fry which he could not fault . We also had some fries for sharing which they served with our own bottle of Jack Daniels BBQ sauce - simply amazing . All this washed down with one of their juice creations made for a great experience . The staff were friendly and attentive , would definitely visit again

_E2yOdLyGvXMSCwIadQl8Q.text: Don't understand the haters. As a New Yorker, the atmosphere made me feel at home. Cocktail culture is on the rise in London and that is a great thing. Plus, I have been here twice now and both times my bartender was extraordinarily friendly and cool. Stop hating on Jackson + Rye.

PbcYdONwGAdcOmmOZ3PZ2A.text: Terrible! Bad coffee (too bitter) and not the right balance of coffee to milk in my flat white. Had the Avocado Benedict - a poached egg perched on top half an avocado with 'shavings' of bacon hidden underneath. Weird, and not at all enjoyable to eat. The toast was a tiny square (no joke) and literally as hard as a brick - didn't even bother. The portion is on the small side and I couldn't finish it.

voo4IaMYw-ZBhxGs9MDKdQ.text: I'm traveling alone on my big-spend, treat yo'self vacation and decided this spot looked good, and it's close to my hotel (W Leicester). The hostess sneers when I request a table for one. Then she says I will have to wait 15-20 minutes (despite the couple in front of me being seated right away). I say, sure I'm willing to wait. She looks upset and then says I should go online and reserve a table on the site and she *might* notify me... or I can leave my name. I give her my name and she doesn't write it down. She blinks at me and slowly says "uh huh come back in 20 minutes." Clearly she does not want to seat me and I don't have a desire to dine somewhere I am not welcome. As I walk out trying to figure out what to do for dinner, I hear her seat the couple behind me. I've never in my life been treated so condescendingly, and I can't believe it was by someone who is part of the hospitality service industry.

1KzJfDLZQ1IpxDNu3qA5CQ.text: We were walking by this place on our way to breakfast at Pret a Manger - and decided to try this instead.   So glad we did this instead - everything we ordered was excellent!  Great juices (green juice was good). and eggs- I liked the Gardener.   If you are looking for a nice breakfast, I definitely recommend you try this place.

gA7KJkMA5sSgCRoAPKja9w.text: Brunch on a Sunday can be difficult to find in London when everyone seems to be serving a Sunday roast. This was the perfect combo of both breakfast and lunch options especially for a southern girl who was missing her fried chicken. Delicious! Their fresh juices and coffee were great additions to the meal and service was spot on - they checked in with us but weren't all over us and let us stay chatting without ordering anything further until we were ready to leave. I will definitely be back for dinner. What a cool place with great food and a lovely vibe.

photos.caption: Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom. Avocado benedict
Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom. Buttermilk fried hickey sandwich with spicy cabbage slaw and chipotle mayo

Z3ZrAIojpxk_kXwXnyCazw.text: Farmer's breakfast with maple bacon is highly recommended, as are the pancakes. I found the service to be both attentive and friendly and the decor charming

QnUAO2jb9fbXIL3MgwattQ.text: Entrance here is bad, bad, bad...Despite that, as well as suspending my thoughts about previous reviews on this place here's my take on J+RI booked for my crew and we had a variety of things from the menu as well as the cocktails.As I said the entrance/reception area is a train wreck. Congested & people on-top-of each other. Please sort that out because it can be a turn off for those of us who take the time to make a reservation. With that said, YES, MAKE A RESERVATION!! I always get annoyed with people who complain about 'service or not getting seated timely' at venues like this that are in Soho and you know darn well that is touristville. BOOK AHEAD! I did & had no issues whatsoever.Onto the staff. I chose to wait for my crew before going to our table so the nice hostess offered me a seat at the bar. Friendly & attractive barmen, kept me entertained without deviating from service to the punters. Nice to be acknowledged.Table ready, we headed to the back. Oh, yeah...this place is not huge. I repeat, BOOK AHEAD! The front area comprises the bar and a few tables for those who prefer people watching. The back area is mainly booths and a few tables which I prefer because the ambiance feels more New York to me opposed to the Parisien front area.We ordered our free cocktails while the rest of my posse arrived and they didn't take forever to get to us either. I had the Duece Royale and it was refreshing and tasty. Right amount of kick for brunch too. My friends had the Black 'n Rye, Bloody Mary and Breakfast Sour - all good and at the right strength for brunch.We had the Shrimp & Grits, which was the winner for me; Angler's, Gardener's, Avocado Benedict, Crab Cakes, Garden Salad and Sea Bass. Everything was so good. Cooked well and service came with lots of smiles. All I can say is that the portions seem to be appetizer sizes, including main dishes. This wouldn't wash in a true USA brunch venue but for London, in Soho, I guess they can try this. Everything was flavourful, seasonsed well and so very filling. We even shared a portion of chips.Thanks to Jackson & Rye for a lovely afternoon.

P0cZinNxoRF2EFvVOTXOUA.text: Walked past here so many times and  always wanted to pop in but never had the time. Took my mum here for a late brunch and I've already chosen what I will have on my return.  For drinks I had Vodka Royal and my mum had Gin Garden both so taste! I then had the avocado Benedict which was a great twist as it just meant it felt like a lighter dish. My mum had the beef has and loved it though was a little dry. The staff were fantastic and so helpful with all our questions.

photos.caption: Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom. Avocado Benedict

VQq0nyyJzJleymXXdTjMZg.text: It's a place to have a decent steak. It's £21 for 200g fillet - it was a little bit on the dry side, but good nevertheless - curbed my cravings for a steak. Side fries were ok and green beans with pecans were good.House sauce which comes free on the table - wasn't that good. Reminded me of a standard BBQ sauce.My friend ordered buttermilk chicken sandwich - it was very good. I'm not a fan of chicken, because meat is normally very dry, but this one was very juicy. I liked it a lot. Perhaps something for the next time.The atmosphere - casual and un-pretentious. I would say go here if you are struggling to find a casual (not too loud) place in Soho. Do book in advance though.Service was very friendly and attentive.

Ufq63sJT30gpUzBgcYV-8g.text: Jackson + Rye is a fairly spacious place modelled along the lines of a upscale American diner and advertises hearty fare inspired by Southern US cooking as well as a range of cocktails and other boozes to get your day started. The décor is mostly small tables and booths and it feels more 1940s than anything else.  Staff are friendly, albeit a bit slow (or perhaps the place was understaffed on Saturday morning), and were quick to greet and exchange a bit of banter. J+R is a bit of a hit and miss on the menu. Given our group of 10, we managed to try out a hefty portion of the brunch menu and in general I think we were a little let down. The menu looks delicious from the shrimp'n'grits to the buttermilk fried chicken and let's not forget the truffled mac'n'cheese. The shrimp'n'grits actually were pretty damn good and reasonably sized and priced for an appetiser. The shrimp were a tad overcooked but the grits textured yet soft. I think a heavier hand with the cheese would have given the dish more oomph but not a bad start. The other half of my meal was the fried squid which looked more like under-cooked onion rings (I like a golden brown look to my batter not a pale tan). Still, they were tasty and the spicy sauce was excellent with a good balance of heat and tanginess. The GF went for the buttermilk fried chicken as we'd just come off a chicken high a few days ago with the Devonshire Arms's offering. Sadly, this must have been one of the scrawnier runts of the brood and lacked even the most basic of seasoning. If you do insist on trying the chicken, get the fried chicken sandwich as that has about 2/3rds the amount of meat but only costs half as much. You'd be better off getting two sandwiches and having more meat as well as a fairly tasty bun and some sauce for flavour.Although our waitress wasn't quite sure about the difference between a flat white and a cappuccino (and indeed looking at the two, I'm not sure the barista did either), the cocktails were excellent. I tried out the Black + Rye which was essentially an espresso martini made with Rittenhouse 100 rye and it was a perfect boozy brunch cocktail. At £6, it's quite reasonably priced, particularly for Soho and a decent size - about the same size as Ape & Bird but for £2 less.

C0ToHOyaENX62qLXv8Ia2w.text: This is really one of my favourite restaurants and bars in London, as it always delivers. Dinners here are always great, and the breakfast/brunch is also amazing. The place has everything going for it - great food, unique and tasty beers and drinks, nice ambiance and really helpful staff. They have great IPAs and other American beer. The bourbon menu is vast. Cocktails and drinks are really innovative and most importantly well-priced for the area.Yesterday we had the cornbread to share, really good with just the right amount of chilli. I had the truffle Mac and cheese for starter, and it was really filling, but most importantly just amazing truffle and parmesan taste. I savoured every bite. Then I had the southern style deep fried chicken breast with sweet potatoe fries. I love this dish and they make it into a sandwhich for brunch as well, but after the Mac and cheese it felt a bit heavy and I came down into a short food-induced coma as all the energy from my brain was diverted to the digestive system... I really wanted dessert but couldn't fit it in.... I should have probably taken something lighter after the Mac and cheese.They have a lot of steak, and I haven't tried them but friend who have say they have been great.Staff seems to be genuinely interested in working there and providing great service, everyone had a smile.Oh and when they are busy, you put your name on their iPad and they text you when a table comes free - so you don't have to wait outside but can grab a drink somewhere closeby while you wait. So really great place to stop by even when you haven't made a reservation. I wish every restaurant had this!

UFnjqTAwPG_lj2ecElydPg.text: I've been here for dinner and breakfast, and I'm pleased to say I'd recommend either. Right at the front is a fantastic looking bar with an glamorous old school New York feel, and just behind it the restaurant opens up to a large seating area. For dinner I've tried the truffle mac & cheese, half lobster, avocado and bacon salad, and the reuben - and I'd be happy to order any of those again! For breakfast I've only ever tried the avocado benedict, which I love. Weekday breakfast service is speedy (I've been here with a party of approximately 20 and we were still served in a timely manner!) and the staff efficient. They also offer soya for coffee and tea, so that's a bonus for me. Evenings the service can feel a bit... pushy. While we were very looked after, we were also *very* looked after and continuously had to ask for additional time to read menus - because no way were we able to make up our minds about what we wanted for dessert less than 1 minute after receiving the menu! It's also very dark at dinner, to the point where on one occasion I know the party I was with weren't the only ones asking to turn the lights up. Still, the food and atmosphere here saves it for me and it's why I know I'll come back.

Y17IK7UxfkbprjbCS0lvKA.text: + upscale American comfort food+ looks appetising + friendly service- small portion size- limited booking availableI came here for lunch on a Saturday. My friend wasn't able to book in advance but we turned up anyway, where the waitress took my details and said a text will be sent when a table frees up, in about half an hour. Sure enough, within half an hour we were sat at the table, wedged between two other couples. It's not spacious but there's enough elbow room to enjoy your meal. The food is a mix of American/Southern comfort food and cafe food, including grit and cornbread. I had their fish cake from the main while my friend went for the ham and egg skillet on the recommendation of the waitress. Both looked great when delivered, although the size is small even for London standard. This may be because they serve "brunch" until evening time (possibly all day?), so while portion size is ok for a light brunch, I did find myself wanting more food after.

Endyk7ihbyqnNsnj4ofvgA.text: Jackson and Rye certainly holds itself out as being a Central London go-to brunch destination and you can find it mentioned on lots of London websites to that effect. You need to book ahead (though not far ahead).The decor in there is lovely. It's surprisingly spacious with a real American feel. The brunch options are plentiful - there is almost too much to choose from. I spotted some amazing eggs benedict being delivered to other tables and I definitely made a good choice with the beef hash with poached eggs and spinach - perfectly poached eggs are a rarity and although the portion doesn't look huge it more than fills you up for the day.The only disappointment was the 'buttermilk chicken'. The menu doesn't make clear that this is essentially a fried chicken sandwich - not necessary what you want first thing in the morning (we booked for 10am as it was the only time available).They will also add on the not-so-discretionary 12.5% service charge, even for tables of 2 or 4. When did London suddenly collectively decide that service would be 12.5%, not 10%, and that 'discretionary' means it's included on your bill??

Jffd2IVQEstW6gpqIPxeaA.text: I had a very pleasant visit at Jackson + Rye in the heart of Soho. I had very nice and polite service all day (I was there quite a long time as I was working). The venue is cool looking during the day as well as in the evening. I was also able to use it for working with a fast free internet and an electricity plug right next to me. Not really much to choose for a vegan but I had a nice avocado salad and sweet potato fries - both delicious :P Will definitely be going again.

photos.caption: Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom

o5oTG9skX8liz5Q80PUQFg.text: Wow, some negative reviews on poor Jackson and Rye. I had a great time here and thought it was a lovely place to hang out. We were around Soho and looking for a place to have dinner when I saw a tweet from J&R about their cocktails so the siren call drew me in. It's really not what I expected and the front bar has a nice old world hotel grandeur feel. We hopped up on two seats at the bar, all the better for ordering drinks! I didn't experience the crush that other people felt and actually thought it was a pretty chilled placed to sit. And the perfect location for spying on what other people had ordered. Oh man, the truffle mac and cheese smells divine! We were being healthy and ordered two salads which were generously portioned with grilled chicken. I had a good experience here, drinks aren't the cheapest but I'd definitely return...For dessert at the very least ;-)

xZ1gZV3yB0GXLvL_LVEbYg.text: I like me a brunch place, but I found new entrant Jackson & Rye was disappointing. I was on the Classy Christmas Crawl organised by Andrew M, attended also by Becky H, and agree with much of what they've said, so will keep it to my main feelings about my experience here:Value is truly terrible. £12 for two pieces of fried chicken, sides extra? Ouch.Quality is so-so. The fried chicken doesn't compare to the excellent fare to be had at the Devonshire Arms in Kensington, for example.Overall. Disappointing, and surprisingly so. New entrants into existing food markets normally fight on something - anything - to gain a foothold against their rivals but J&R don't seem to be bothering with that. A glass of bubbles for those checking in on Facebook is nice, sure, but c'mon, it's hardly enough to draw punters away from established rivals. I hope for the sake of everyone working here that the management comes up with something more substantial to tempt in Soho's brunch crowd, because there is no shortage of worthy alternatives nearby.

NZXSfrJlgR0hoG0mo_hfFQ.text: Nice interior with dim lighting and appropriate decor. Serves decent cocktails and food. Popular for their Rye collection and Southern Fried chicken, which I found to be tasty but a bit over done and too soggy. Excellent grits. Dining at the bar is also available.

photos.caption: Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom. El Paso Sour

z1V2az39StP5hcdJEaxJRw.text: We thought it would be a good idea to find some great american style meal for a change.   Jackson and Rye looked great online and the menu seemed great.Service was''t great.  We had to call the water over to get water and to order after 15 mins. We ordered as we didn't have much time and had to get back to work.  The food came quickly which was great.  I ordered  seafood linguine pasta.  It looked very plane, not fresh and not hot - a little sad looking really.   I tasted it and it was dry and tasteless.  Rather than offering, I also had to ask the waitress for parmesan cheese (to bring some more flavour to the meal).    I also bit into one of the calms and it had a really bad taste.  After that I had to stop eating as I was concerned about the quality of fish.   My other half ordered Reuben and was very much looking forward to a stacked pastrami meat Rueben with dressing (like you get in American - particularly New York).   It arrived with very little meat and almost NO thousand island dressing - or anything else you get in a Reuben.  It was awful.  He also order chips that you could tell had been sitting around for some time.   Bad taste, dry and chewy!   Don't waste your money at this place.  It's pretending to be American but doesn't live up in any way to what you get in America.... as a matter if fact, it's just plain awful.  Don't bother.

b1U_tID4ddPX6nnbLzF0sg.text: The first time I went there, I was disgruntled at being shown to a gloomy dark corner downstairs on a very sunny day despite having booked ages in advance. Despite the grim mood, I liked the fare on offer, distinctly American in its offerings such as jalapeno corn bread, grits, fried potatoes, etc along with the usual brunch suspects of eggs, pancakes, etc. It's also nice that they have some regular lunch mains (including steaks!) and sandwiches for those who don't fancy the brunch menu.Purely because of the menu, I decided to go back there and this time I specified an upstairs table in my booking request and we got a booth for a group, yay. The experience was much nicer. The pomegranate/orange/pink grapefruit juice was tasty but a bit of a small serving especially with all the ice. Big fan of the eggs served as Gardener's (vegetarian) & Angler's (with smoked salmon) and the corn bread. A friend ordered pancakes and the portion size was huge for the price. All in all, this is a good spot for casual dining. A note on their service, they seem to tend towards slightly trendy/snooty sorely missing the point of cheerful American service, but even so, it's acceptable enough...

GjqUV661eS-NRbGNOtlXyw.text: I liked the look of the place, and it reminded me of some great places I've been to in the US. The service was very professional and friendly and was the other positive note, however the food did not impress.The fried chicken was soggy and wasn't great value considering it didn't come with sides. The mac and cheese was too runny, the fries were ok; the corn grits were pretty good though. The menu got our hopes up but we left feeling a bit disappointed.This place has some things going for it but they need to step up the quality of the food before I would go back.

9xHEukuUVUKqUUASFJbz3A.text: OMG love love love breaded buttermilk chicken, slaw and sweet potato fries. We were seated downstairs initially but it was so loud I could hardly hear myself think! The staff were very accommodating and moved us upstairs which was much better. This is great American food and excellent service.

etbYndHTaE9ix43Q4h-ghQ.text: Good American style bar with a proper Dark and Stormy. Did also try their Dark and Stormy float, tasty and different.Didn't eat but would come back.

IPyTwXv2vveurk-YfT6yVw.text: I have had the farmers breakfast which consists of eggs sausage slab bacon pan fried potatoes and toast. Pork fatty. Crunchy. Crispy. Lovely. It's raining outside.

KGrWf3_vIgDuBwY7aRaZ2Q.text: Some pretty solid food at this establishment. I was skeptical at first because not many restaurants that are not in southern states in the United States can execute grits, but this restaurant did an excellent job! I ordered the shrimp and grits, and the pulled pork tacos, they were both absolutely delicious. The tacos were sweet, spicy, savory, and had wonderful textures. The grits were under seasoned, but the consistency was executed perfectly. I didn't mind the grits being under seasoned because I prefer to add my own, plus the shrimp were packed with flavor. This restaurant has further intensified my love for the United Kingdom. Definitely check them out!

photos.caption: Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom. Shrimp and grits. Excellent!

0gvQAgkDUm_usTg2rirsZQ.text: J+R gets four stars for decor and ambiance. I love the feel of this place and someone has given the space a lot of thought. Very cool!The slight letdown is the food. It wasn't horrible by any means but it solidly reminded me of Denny's. Don't get me wrong - I love Denny's!  Solid middle American chain food. Five of us came for a low key meal. We shared:Cornbread: served hot with a nice kick with the jalapeño peppers but oddly served with sour cream and scallions. I wanted a nice ball of whipped butter!!Popcorn: £1.50 for a tiny portion. C'mon people. It's popcorn. Popcorn is dirt cheap. You can afford to be a little more generous. Olives: bland olives!I won't comment on the other mains but I had the chopped salad. It was good. Although would have appreciated the chicken being chopped too. Again, it was like a Denny's salad, down to the glass plate it was served on!Not a bad experience but I'd go back for the ambience rather than the food. Probably a better spot for drinks!

2AibfeEX51QPPRSNkhG0pQ.text: Stopped in to get out of the rain and grab a quick drink and a snack. We were greeted promptly by two employees with great big smiles! We were seated immediately and glasses of water were brought to our table while we decided on what drinks to order... wine! We ordered spicy nuts, chicken wings, and bread/butter. They're to die for! So tasty. So hot. Good people watching at the front tables too. Free wifi. Good rock-n-roll playing on the speakers... Rock on with yer bad self!

o-3jNUwEL8ebqxrPgLaPQg.text: My friends and I ended up at Jackson + Rye as we couldn't get booked at Kopapa or Dishoom for brunch and we needed to be near Leicester Square for some Sing-a-long action at the Prince Charles cinema....This was our first time at any of the Jackson + Rye restaurants, they have more near the river in Chiswick & Richmond, my friend was especially excited to see steak & bourbon on the brunch menu! The Soho branch entrance was tucked under some scaffolding and when we entered it seemed busy & buzzing, the bar area immediately in front and the place full of dark wood paneling.We were led downstairs into the dimly lit basement and ordered some of their fabulous drip coffees to wake us up - they certainly worked a treat, especially as alcohol wasn't sold 'til midday - we had arrived at a respectable brunch time of 11am... They don't advertise the licensing limits anywhere!Whilst waiting for our final friend to arrive we started off by ordering some of the snacks - the truffle arancini and jalapeño corn bread were amazing! The arancini a decadent hit of truffle oil and cheese and the corn bread warm straight out of the oven, served with sour cream to muffle the kick if you got a whole chunk of the chili.Despite the slow service, we were now anticipating the 'mains' (and the prosecco at midday!)So how did they stand up? Well my brunch was the avocado eggs Benedict - with crispy bacon, which was fabulous and made me happy. Lauren had the corn beef hash - again very tasty.Tiva had steak and eggs and a 'side' of banana cream pancakes - and OMG they were stunning. The banana cinnamon cream with maple syrup was sublime on the American style stack - worth ordering! Ellen had another steak (no eggs!) and a side of Mac and cheese - I have never been so happy that my dining companions were willing to share food :)We quickly necked back two bottles of prosecco with the food (not wanting to wait while the bar woke up and got to grips with cocktails! Our coffees took long enough to come!). I would definitely want to come back here when they've gotten the staff trained and ironed out the small issues, there's a whole menu of cocktails to try with brunch! (But only after midday....)

BTaV0y4jY-h1YMAxocFqXA.text: I've had my eyes on this place since the closure of Satsuma (that used to be there). Jackson + Rye it said on the sign, with that cool font they're using and in my head I assumed a rather nice all-day place. Yep, I was right.Nicely decorated . Think something from early 20th century meets Upper West Side and pops up in London's Soho. A beautiful place, dark but also loud and jammed with people. I've gone to it a day before opening, they were somehow open and without a booking we managed to get a table right away (Tuesday, 8 PM in Soho right before Christmas).We were given menus quickly and asked if we wanted some water and some nibbles before the main deal. We nodded.Soon, we received some olives that seemed to have been marinated in a mixture of brine and orange rind along with some 'filtered' water.On to the main deal, we got a salad to share and two main courses. When the food arrived, it hit me. This is run by the same people who own Grillshack. The resemblance was striking. Same sad plates, same shoestring and 'normal' fries. Same simplicity, not in a good way.So the minute steak was OK and the buttermilk fried chicken was delicious. That was some of the best chicken I've ever had. But the coleslaw was soggy and our salad, well, our salad looked like it had been taken out of the late 80s. I don't have a picture but lookwise it was not inviting. Flavourwise, it was OK. It wasn't special for a salad worth a tenner. 4 satisfactory pieces of (cold) bacon were on the sides and a couple broken pecans. Blue cheese sauce was good.Trying to hide our disappointment and drink our mediocre house wine we decided  that YOLO and we got desserts. So we ordered the apple fritters and the pretzel shake. Apple fritters were delicious, but at £6.95 for 2 pieces rather expensive.  Pretzel milkshake tasted like milk with little pieces of crushed pretzel (couldnt taste the bourbon or anything sweet).The service was excellent and despite being seated in the corner we got all the attention we required - quite surprising for a brand new spot.I don't really know what to think of this place. The food is nothing special, nothing I'd go and spend that amount of money on. You pay a lot for its location. There's excellent ambiance and apparently their cocktails are their biggest strength. However, for food that tastes just as Grillshack, I'd rather go straight there and spend less than half.

photos.caption: Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom

9Wq0OrwUq2AnLQbFwhsOIw.text: So close Jackson + Rye, so close.I've walked past the front of Jackson + Rye time and time again from inception to opening to post production, well, not quite post production. I'll start with this, it's in a great location and it's very attractive, the space inside is a bit on the tight side, but I get it, space is expensive.Having heard great things about Jackson + Rye for it's brunch / breakfast, I thought, if it's been well reviewed for brunch, I should probably go for dinner. What tipped the scale and made me set foot in this restaurant was the great deal offered on the 'lunch menu', which incidentally, runs until 6.30pm (what kind of lunch is that). Not one to complain, we popped inside and ordered both the lobster macaroni and the flat iron steak with a salad instead of chips (I know, I know, it was the health drive).When I ordered the flat iron steak, I wasn't actually asked how I wanted my steak, which made me uneasy. However, when it arrived on my table. It was perfectly pink in the middle. Fortunately for me, that's how I like my steaks. The steak was very well seasoned and it was a perfect piece of meat on it's own. It was accentuated by a sauteed onion, which was very welcome. A few strands of greens on the side was completely superfluous though. The salad that this came with was...odd. It was basically half an iceberg lettuce covered with a creamy salad sauce. Although it was quite refreshing and the crunchiness went well the the steak and onion, it wasn't what I was expecting as a 'salad', it wasn't even a poor man's Caesar. I left feeling very confused.The lobster macaroni came with succulent pieces of lobster on top (for a mere £9.90). More than I expected, which is always nice. The macaroni cheese was pretty standard - not cheesy enough for strands of cheese to pull at the escaping macaroni, but still filling and creamy. The drinks here were a no no, the mixed fruit juice came out of a V8 carton (I'm guessing here) and was overtly sweet. The 'homemade lemonade' tasted like lemon juice squeezed into sparkling water. Maybe should've gone for something alcoholic...but then again, before 6.30pm?I will probably be back for the steak alone.

photos.caption: Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom. Whole spread
Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom. Good steak

d2jUbrowtM-LhOKp-OS04A.text: To kick off the Classy Christmas Crawl organised by Andrew M, we had brunch at Jackson and Rye at 1pm. While a few people were late, most of us were seated and ready to order by 1:20.  Our server asked us if we wanted anything to drink, and there was a promo where you will get a free glass of champagne upon a FB check-in.  We told him all 10 of us were in the process of checking in, but it took ages for the drinks to arrive.  Granted it was free - but by 1:45, we were still getting our champagne poured, and itching to order as we had to be out of the resto by 2:30.  I do like that their turnaround time in the kitchen was pretty quick once the food was ordered, as we received the bill by that time. I was excited to try Jackson and Rye, as their menu looked awesome, but I was a bit disappointed in quality of the meal.  I had the truffle mac 'n cheese to start, which was £7 - I think thats the most expensive and smallest mac n cheese I've ever had. It was definitely a side size rather than appy size.  While it tasted truffly, I was really put off by the watery cheese consistency.  Everyone has who shared a bite thought the same thing.  My buttermilk fried chicken was £12, and I thought it was bland and not so great.  It was 2 fillets of chicken with a side of slaw (which I didn't care for) and a wedge of lemon.  It was crispy on the top, but on the bottom, there was a big section of mushy batter,which was off-putting.  (On a side note, if you'd like some amazing fried chicken, visit Devonshire Arms in S Ken)I was disappointed in the £12 value of the chicken. I know its the Soho area, but it was a really skimpy portion of food.  I think this was highlighted when others ordered the buttermilk fried chicken sandwich - and their chicken was MASSIVE, along with a topping of coleslaw and bun for £7.  My 2 pieces of chicken combined probably made up 1.5x the size of the chicken burger batty.  So the rest of us who ordered the chicken felt a bit gypped that it cost an extra £5 to essentially skip the bun and get another 1/2 order of chicken fillet.  While the kitchen turnaround time for food was fast, our server was a bit on the slow side to start off.  The overall food experience was just kinda meh to me and poor value for the quality.  Nothing that fantastic here.

photos.caption: Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom. Buttermilk fried chicken 12
Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom. 7 truffle mac n cheese. Dish looks big but it's more like a small side, shallow layer of mac

mXQX9VJGatl_hb7YabveLQ.text: Just went for breakfast this morning - everything was fine and service was fine as well.  I had the prison eggs which are scrambled w beans and spring onion mixed in.   For me it was quite a bit of beans!  I think they would have been better on the side.  But still a good and filling dish.  Comes with good toast and butter and I believe it was £ 6.5. I ordered the pancakes w maple syrup for my kids it was fine as well. They have a number of interesting breakfast cocktails on the list but just note that they only serve After 10 Am

Hl4-SnkNUx2hv9cwt1NdEQ.text: I'm not sure why this place only has three stars. Maybe we got lucky.Went for breakfast with my girlfriend. Everything was fantastic: the bacon was thick and tasty, potatoes were delicious, eggs cooked to perfection, tea was tasty and service was great. We both really enjoyed our meal and it ended up being one of our best breakfasts of our European tour.The atmosphere is cool too. The place has plenty of seating and the bathrooms are really big and clean.Can't rate it on their lunch or dinner, but for breakfast I don't think you can go wrong with this place. In my opinion it earned all five stars.

WkNb6hfIQapGEgzGcOrFJQ.text: Mixed review on this restaurant. Food: Food for the most part was delicious. Ordered the pulled pork cups, crab cakes, fried chicken and mac and cheese and it was all above average and very tasty! Ordered the burger and the fries that came with it were extremely undercooked. Had to send the fries back and they gave us new fries which were OK but still not very crispy. Service: Service wasn't great all night. They forgot about our table for the majority of the night. Took 40 minutes simply to place our order, another 30 minutes minutes to bring out drinks etc - very slow and rude service. The food came and we still hadn't even been given cutlery! They didn't even apologize for their slow service.

cARJdSZRfyUiYwtqPJcUDg.text: Heading to Jackson+Rye on a beautifully sunny day I was worried about getting consigned to the gloomy basement that other reviewers mention. Thankfully with a reservation we had no problems.Service was nice but a little haphazard, with my order slightly wrong the first time around. The Full American breakfast was delicious, and my friend's pancakes were also great. Good value as well, for a restaurant in Soho prices were exceptionally reasonable. Cocktails were also okay, if nothing special.I'd probably head back there again to check out the fried chicken and the desserts as they looked exceptional. Seemed like a good place to hang out with a big group as well.

5RgwXf-Mdy-4Io_1QUjhpA.text: My friend Paul and I popped in for lunch and were both impressed by the decor and spacious layout. Jackson + Rye feels classy but maintains a casual atmosphere. I ordered the Buttermilk Fried Chicken with spicy coleslaw, which was a bit pricey for the portion size at £11.95 and was sadly suffering from a soggy bottom... I washed down the disappointment with a delicious Barrel Manhattan (£8).Paul had the Lobster Mac & Cheese with crispy parmesan topping, which was a blue plate special at £9.95 and was well cooked, full of delicious flavours and contained a generous amount of lobster.Either we were particularly hungry this lunch time or the portions were a bit small but either way, we both had desserts - Paul had the Melting Chocolate Sundae with butterscotch sauce and popping candy for £6.50, which was as tasty as it sounds and I had a nice Baked Potted Cheesecake with berry compôte at £5.95 - again, a bit on the steep side for what you get.

9SwWgZdFgXB8pVKgjkWihw.text: Wow, was I excited about coming here. Looking at the (very comprehensive) menu beforehand, I thought Jackson & Rye might be the exact American Breakfast fix I was looking for.First off, the tables are jammed in. The space between ours and the one next to it was minuscule - always makes for a nice awkward private-public conversation. Not a place for relaying any big news or exciting gossip.When it came to ordering, we grappled with a waiter who spoke so quietly and so fast that I still, even after asking him to repeat what he was saying several times, have no idea what he was trying to tell us.The food was good, and arrived swiftly, and the bill was pleasantly low for the middle of Soho.Unfortunately, and I can't really put my finger on why, I don't have any desire to go back. By the time breakfast was over, I wanted to get out of there before they'd even cleared the plates. Please do let me know if I'm entirely wrong, but I really wasn't impressed with the whole experience, and so my search for the best American breakfast in London continues.

H3sVmQbKH0XEGZTpTpq6Fw.text: Good service and decent food. They were out of porterhouse tonight, but were able to offer two other cuts of meat. Also had the friend chicken, which was pretty good. A lot of the breading fell off though. The truffle Mac and cheese was ok, but I wouldn't bother ordering it again.

j4DRTjyVHOjaz6TUo4Zw4Q.text: The drinks were great. The black and rye was amazing. Main courses were just ok. The appetizers were much better. The truffle Mac and cheese is a must. I am sure there are other places in the area with better food but you should totally come here for the drinks.

photos.caption: Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom. Black and Rye

YvMi0iuqASIoiMXxMskuOA.text: Pros = Very good service, nice chill atmosphere, good food which is not excessively priced.Cons = Some of the tables are a little small.Most recently I had:Chowder = Pretty good (portion size was a little small).Philly Cheese Steak = Not on the à la carte menu, but available on the theatre meal deal before 18:30 on weekdays. The bun was a little dry, but the steak filling was excellentPecan pie = Really good. Verdict = I would definitely eat here again.

gq2WedsCNfGusEErMb-oQQ.text: One word to sum up this restaurant: OK! Good starters, sides and mains -- but all of them miss that special something -- be that a sauce on the burger or spices in the corn mash. But in an area where all the good restaurants have at least 45 minute wait this jump-straight-in restaurant works.And you really have to wait for the waiters...

2o5MVkvuDZ_dR6YCmmlF0Q.text: Nice place for lunch and brunch. Better ask for a table on the top, downstairs is a bit smelly. The food is good, brunch around 15£ with drinks like juice. The dessert are really good! Try the chocolate sundae ;)Poor service, the waitress are really slow.

photos.caption: Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom

6sq_alKpw90cwQkYte0brg.text: I'm surprised to read people's poor reviews of Jackson + Rye. I found my visit to be one of the best demonstrations of customer service anyone could ask for. We visited really late in the evening, right before they stopped serving food and transition into bar. They squeezed us in despite it almost being time for the kitchen to close and the staff were really friendly and accommodating. We had some great cocktails, delicious buttermilk fried chicken and the truffle mac & cheese is amazing. All the food we ate was fantastic. I would definitely come here again - great selection of comfort food and I loved my gooey marshmallow dessert. Yum!

mA39fMlctTea5tdpNecXlQ.text: Friendly service. Great atmosphere. Awesome cocktail bar. Best fried chicken in London all at a reasonable price for soho.

PGyJ7dgewr9TwdYQ-LbqFw.text: We were walking around and found this place.  Food was really good and we got to sit by the window and people watch out the window.  Full bar of course.  It was a bit pricey, but you get plenty of food.  It was walking distance from our hotel and there is a pick up and drop off for the Big Bus tour nearby.

photos.caption: Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom. Breakfast menu

4qrjBmUA1enMTv9ozmPC7w.text: Breakfast at 9:45 am on a Sunday morning. I searched for "places to eat American breakfast in London" and this was recommended. They have several locations and this was the only one open on Sunday. They took reservations for breakfast so I made one. When I showed first thing they asked was if we had reservations even though they were not full. We were 10 minutes late and had one more in the party but they still took us. The seating as not comfortable, small table with lots of traffic around us, but I was just glad to be seating. The service was friendly, and the food delivery fast. I did order a personal drip coffee and the girl that delivered it did not know how to use it. It was delivered to my table without the coffee grounds but they fixed that quickly. I ordered the Farmers and it was great. I especially appreciated getting something close to American bacon in London. The baked beans were a nice surprise, and the eggs and toast enjoyable. Others in my party ordered omelettes and enjoyed them. Be aware that a 12.5% gratuity is automatically added to the ticket. Very fair. Overall great experience for breakfast. Don't forget to make reservations. A return visit is in order if time permits on this trip.

photos.caption: Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom. Farmer's breakfast

HB4jGmQrWofSkcb4x9yMAQ.text: Ordered ham and cheese omelette. It is delicious, especially the potatoes that accompanied it. Very quaint space. Great and attentive service. Food is better than the"popular" places in my opinion.

rUP-VdIgbivzuVzwgDmBTg.text: This place has become a faithful back-up suggestion for brunch in central London with a group at only a few days notice - such spots are a real rarety! I booked in with my girls for a Saturday, and was very glad to have done so when we saw the queue trailing out the door...The inside was packed, and the service a little slow as a result, but you could still appreciate the grandeur of the bar area. The menu is extensive (another reason it's a faithful suggestion - covers the picky eaters!) and our choices spanned eggy dishes to more lunchtime options. I really enjoyed my Forager breakfast which came with eggs, halloumi, kale, mushrooms, avo, spiced black beans and a slice of granary. All followed by a bite of my friend's caramelised banana pancakes to finish on a sweet note :)A spot for quiet relaxing time this is not, but for a more lively catch-up you can't beat the buzzy central soho location. I'm sure I'll be back again when I can't get a booking somewhere more original!

2TJRRdu7MJKQR_L7mtMubQ.text: Worst brunch place ever! It took them 40 mins to serve two portions of eggs that should take no more than 10 mins. Servers were polite but they were sparse.  After 40 mins, the eggs were horrible- how do you mess up poached eggs? I guess ask them for the secret. I would not go back.

js6SVzEHnz_mq7-ZT6cWfw.text: Excellent breakfast food near Piccadilly. Avocado "Royale" is excellent and my daughter loved the Huevos Rancheros. They also have excellent smoothies.

iO7yt0E721obqPgzAnOt2A.text: This place was awesome. Great food choices and a fantastic bar selection. Try the clam chowder. Really cool presentation. Don't fill up. Dessert is definitely a must. They got very busy late night but provided excellent and friendly service.

photos.caption: Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom. Steak with fries
Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom. Clam chowder

eLVg69UqzMkkS5pX7-GzAg.text: In a city that's often full of egregiously flawed preconceived notions regarding the local cuisine, Jackson + Rye really does fall short of expectation.  Star 1: How were the service and atmosphere?One thing that certainly isn't lacking at Jackson + Rye is the atmosphere - and the service as well. Located conveniently whether you're out for a meal or seeking a bit of reprieve from the drink, you can expect to be seated swiftly and from a server crew with smiles on their faces. While I'll admit my server was exceptionally slow with regard to refilling waters and settling the bill, that doesn't overshadow what was otherwise a very pleasant experience. Star 2: How were the portions relative to the cost?As nothing on the menu really blew me away with respect to the main dishes, my entire party opted to combo two starters into a meal. My truffled mac n cheese and half lobster were a suitable amount of food for what was a combined £19.20 - fair for a full meal. Star Granted. Stars 3 and 4: How was the food?It was here that everything went wrong. The truffled mac n cheese? soupy, and lacking any flavor resembling truffles whatsoever. The pasta was overcooked, the crumbled top overdone, and the flavors simply absent from a dish that should otherwise be creamy and flavorful. The half lobster was equally poor, with little meat to speak of in a skeleton that was clearly overcooked as well. No butter dip? Interesting. All in all, this was poor across the board. No Stars Granted. Star 5: Would you eat here every day if you could?London is absolutely stacked on fabulous dining, but Jackson + Rye falls well short of the curve with regard to quality of food. No Star Granted.

photos.caption: Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom. Half Lobster: 12.95
Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom. Truffled Mac n Cheese: 6.25

qDzhGG4bPqoXby-O465ZOw.text: We ate in here on a recent trip to London. We managed to get a same day booking, which I hear in a central London location, is no mean feat! It was busy, but I loved the atmosphere. The decor was beautiful - kind of like a 1940s Manhattan feel. The music was great too. The thing that made this review miss 5 stars was the service. I guess it's just London service. We were served by a Scottish guy, but he conned us out of £2.75 in the first thirty seconds by asking if we wanted "still or sparkling" water. Rookie error - still isn't tap water. So if you want water for the table, ask for tap water! We did have an in depth discussion about a Scot conning fellow Scots though...On to the food. Wow! We both love American barbeque and Southern Food. We got the J&R BBQ board to share which consisted of Buffalo Wings, Ribs, Beef Brisket and chips. It was more than enough for the two of us. We also got popcorn chicken and truffle and polenta hush puppies to share too. The food was smoky and delicious and tasted quite genuine too. Again, for a central London location, the price was reasonable at just under £50 for the dinner. A must visit if you're in Soho!

EQ5fnrCRZNO8zkZ6-JkIRw.text: Stumbled upon this London treasure while walking to the flat we rented.  I had the raved about buttermilk chicken and it was surprisingly good.  Another visit I had the Cajun Grilled Swordfish and thought I died and went to heaven! The atmosphere is comfortable, loud and fun. The staff are attentive and helped each other out with tables.  I'll say there's very interesting people watching to be had here when you sit near the windows!

photos.caption: Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom. Bar area

eTByvcm2XmgkAKFDvmy2zw.text: Worst service ever. Waiters were rude, food was cold, and not good. Found hair in my food that didn't belong to me and when I pointed it out to the waiter he argued with me that it was mine.

qnOC9LwESMbhhCmNpWidlg.text: Tuesday night, no reservation and looking for pancakes...Well, we didn't find pancakes, The Breakfast Club was fully booked, we didn't want to go the Diner and pancakes here were only available in the morning.No tables, but offered seats at the bar, it was actually a bit more fun than at a table, we had some banter with the bartender and probably slightly quicker service.The barbecue/fried chicken combo was really good, the fried chicken taking the lead. Cajun grilled chicken was also given a thumbs up.The mulled cider was their Christmas cocktail and arrived with a cinnamon stick and spices floating in it. A pleasant meal at the last minute and we both left happy.Try the polenta and truffle hush puppies, little balls of goodness!

zxnOPzB68MW1neQEsaFjew.text: Fantastic breakfast. Undoubtedly the best. Ordered the avocado with smoked salmon and scrambled eggs and Friend potatoes with caramelised onions. The avocado was really fresh and went extremely well with the savoury taste of the smoked salmon. The scrambled eggs were done to perfection which was accentuated by the watercress. The potatoes were very flavourful especially with the nice touch of caramelised onions. All in, definitely well worth the visit and would be back again for more. The service was really good and attentive and the ambience was Amazing to have breakfast while watching the world go by :)

photos.caption: Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom. Having an amazing breakfast while watching the world go by
Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom. Chillax and amazing ambience. Having breakfast while watching the world go by

AQc_2OvRCtA-NzvN_ffOqw.text: Met up with a friend for brunch one Saturday morning. We each ordered a cornbeef hash, espresso, shared a mac and cheese, he had a beer, i had a bloody mary. I'll run down each item.Cornbeef hash - wasn't a hash. Was cold home fries, pastrami from a packet, cold hollandaise sauce and overcooked poached eggs.Espresso - ColdMac and cheese - ok. Nothing  special,Beer - had to ask twice for itBloody mary - I ordered a 'smokey' one which must have had a few tablespoons of liquid smoke dumped in.Service. Best summed up by the following exchange:"All done""Yes, with these but you can leave the mac and cheese""Leave it?""Yes please"*takes mac and cheese*

HpzCK96tF1y6ISrV81UDSA.text: This place really reminded me of home. Could have been in the west village and would not have noticed. Had the avocado eggs Benedict. Poached eggs and the hollandaise sat on top of a bacon stuffed avocado. Potatoes and greens were also a nice touch. Potatoes came with some green onions and caramelized shallots. Coffee served with warmed milk unlike in the U.S. Which is better off. Walked in and accommodated me even though it was pretty busy

photos.caption: Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom. Avocado eggs Benedict

-wsgFUeyk7sZ-Ex8Psl11Q.text: I had Avocado Benedict!! Awesome! Also had an order of home made pancakes with blueberries. Great place . Good service as well.

6UVsmvLY7x7sFTgMLF7adQ.text: Visited Jackson + Rye for a late Sunday brunch with two girlfriends. When we arrived they couldn't find our booking, but to be fair we had left a message to change it last minute, and they were helpful with finding us a table.The decor within Jackson + Rye is dark and a little claustrophobic, but there's a definite buzz and a young crowd. Sadly this did seem to translate into a slight arrogance / snobbiness within at least one of the staff, who wasn't particularly helpful when I requested to swap an item from my dish. It also took 15-20 minutes from arrival for us to get a drink, which seems excessive even when it's reasonably busy.That said, the food is good - I had the vegetarian breakfast and enjoyed the mix of potatoes, halloumi, eggs, beans, spinach, tomatoes, kale and toast. The prices are also reasonable - less than £9 for the breakfast itself (fairly standard for London and less than you might expect for Wardour Street). Overall I do feel that the restaurant has a slight vibe of being too cool for school, which might be off putting for some, and I personally would enjoy the venue much more if it took on a friendly, welcoming atmosphere.

photos.caption: Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom. Vegetarian breakfast

MoE5vRBdXeub_DSAbEIDdA.text: Went on a Sunday for brunch around 3pm. Food was alright I guess, however they got our order wrong and took 20 minutes for a portion of mac and cheese to come out. Service was really poor in general - always so disappointing when there are so many other great restaurants in the area to find a dud like this.Do yourself a favor and look elsewhere.

edix_eqY_MPPhuTtNF7zPQ.text: Went for Sunday brunch. Was welcomed with super friendly staff and smiles. It was a breath of fresh air from the usual empty welcome from most London restaurants. The staff was very attentive and checked on our table regularly. Wish the buttermilk pancakes was a main size instead of appetizer. It was delic. True American style- slight crispiness on the outside, fluffy on the inside. Also ordered the yogurt & granola. Yogurt was very liquid/soup-like. Would be better if they had a thicker yogurt. Ordered the fresh orange juice. Unpleasant surprise, there was (lots of) ice in the cup. In my opinion, a way restaurants skimp out on fresh squeezed juice by filling the cup with ice. Overall, food was good, staff very friendly. The menu looks interesting and good so looking forward to checking it out in the future.Also, great ambiance. Cozy, feel good, and not obnoxiously loud.

photos.caption: Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom. Angler's
Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom. Buttermilk pancakes
Photo of Jackson + Rye - London, United Kingdom. Granola & Yogurt

tYub6a0uEeGHOeSxSsoL2w.text: This is an excellent weekend brunch spot, serving all the way until 4:30 PM on Saturdays and Sundays.  They have bar seating, which is always great while I am on business trips, plus a few tables and some downstairs space as well.  The "Brunch" menu was mostly lunch/dinner options with the exception of 8 or so egg dishes and some pancake choices; however, this was not a problem, because everything I ordered was delicious. The Bloody Mary was very well done, and the avocado-based Benedicts were unique and hit the spot.I wandered down here after I walked by The Breakfast Club Soho, but was turned off by the line (a line for brunch at nearly 4 PM on a Saturday is never worth it, in my opinion).  I was very glad to find this place nearby, which had no wait and a very friendly staff.  Will definitely return!
